column2: > HTML pages are text documents.> HTML uses tags, which are characters that sit inside angled brackets.  They act like containers and tell you something about the information that lies between them.> Tags are often referred to as elements.> Tags usually come in pairs.  The opening tag denotes the start of a piece of content; the closing tag denotes the end.> Opening tags can carry attributes which tell us more about the content of that element.> Attributes require a name and a value.> To learn HTML you need to know what tags are available for you to use, what they do, and where they can go.
> Headings and paragraphs> Bold, italic, emphasis> Structural and semantic markup

Markup = Adding tagsStructural markup = The elements that you use to describe both headings and paragraphs.Semantic markup = Provides extra information; such as where emphasis is placed in a sentence, that something you have written is a quotation, the meaning of acronyms, and so on.
ProfStephen Hawking is a threoretical physicist and cosmologist.

> HTML elements are used to describe the structure of the page (e.g. headings, subheadings, paragraphs).> They also provide semantic information (e.g. where emphasis should be placed, the definition of any acronyms used, when given text is a quotation).
> Numbered lists> Bullet lists> Definition lists

1. Chop potatoes into quarters.
    2. Simmer for 15 min.
    3. Heat milk.
    4. Drain potatoes.
    5. Mix wit milk.

• 1kg Potatoes
    • 100ml milk
    • 50g salted butter
    • salt and pepper to taste

<dl></dl>	Definition List<dt></dt>	Definition Term<dd></dd>	Definition<dl>	<dt>Sashimi</dt>	<dd>Sliced raw fish served with condiments.</dd>	<dt>Scale</dt>	<dd>Device used to accurately measure weight.</dd>	<dt>Scamorzo</dt>	<dd>An Italian cheese usually made from whole cow's milk.</dd></dl>

> There are three types of HTML lists: ordered, unordered, and definition.> Ordered lists use numbers.> Unordered lists use bullets.> Definition lists are used to define terminology.> Lists can be nested inside one another.

column2: Structure: Root is the top-level folder.Relationships: Family-tree terminology (parent, children, siblings, etc.)Homepages: homepage should be index.htmlURL: Uniform Resource LocatorURL: Domain Name + PathRoot Folder Contains: index.html, individual foldersEach Sub-directory Contains: index.html for each section, subsequent files for each page.Example:examplearts (root)	index.htmlimages	logo.gifmovies	cinema		index.html		listings.html		reviews.html	dvd		index.html		reviews.htmlmusic	index.html	listings.html	reviews.htmltheater	index.html	listings.html	reviews.html

column2: > How to add images to pages.> Choosing the right format.> Optimizing images for the web.
> Include an image in your web pages using HTML.> Pick which image format to use.> Show an image at the right size.> Optimize an image for use on the web to make pages load faster.

Images Should...> Be Relevant> Convey Information> Convey the Right Mood> Be Instantly Recognisable> Fit the color paletteStock Photos:www.istockphoto.comwww.gettyimages.comwww.veer.comwww.sxc.huwww.fotolia.com

column2: *HTML5 and new websites should use CSS to control alignment of images horizontally (p 411-412). left right ""HTML5 and new websites should use CSS to control alignment of images"
*HTML5 and new websites should use CSS to control alignment of images vertically (p. 285-286). top middle bottom ""HTML5 and new websites should use CSS to control alignment of image"
1. Save images in the right format (usually jpeg, gif, png).2. Save images at the right size (in pixels).3. Measure images in pixels (not cm or in).

Software			Online EditorsAdobe Photoshop		www.photoshop.comPixelmator			www.pixlr.comPaintShopPro			www.splashup.comPaint.net 			www.ipiccy.com* GIMP is good free option.* PhotoShop Elements is cheaper version, good for beginners.* Watch videos to demonstrate how to resize images and save to correct format.
Use GIF or PNG if few colors or large areas of same color (flat colors); like logos, illustrations, diagrams.

Resolution independent.  Commonly created in programs like Adobe Illustrator.  Advantage is that they can increase the dimensions without affecting quality.  First save bitmap image into vector.  Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) used to display directly to the web; thus eliminating need to create bitmap versions first) however, new and not widespread.
Animated GIFs show several frames of an image in sequence and therefore can be used to create simple animations.

Transparent GIF: If transparent part has straight edges and is 100% transparent (not semi-opaque).PNG: If transparent part has diagonal or rounded edges or if you want semi-opaque transparency or drop-shadow.
Checking Size: Right click (Mac: CTRL + click)

column2: > The element is used to add images to a web page. > You must always specify an src attribute to indicate the source of an image and an alt attribute to describe the content of an image. > You should save images at the size you will be using them on the web page and in the appropriate format. > Photographs are best saved as JPEGs; illustrations or logos that use flat colors are better saved as GIFs.

> How to create tables.> What information suits tables.> How to represent complex data in tables.

Date Income Expenditure
1st January 250 36
2nd January 285 48
31st January 129 64
7824 1241
Don't use: width=" cellpadding=" cellspacing="<table width=400" cellpadding="10" cellspacing="5">
Don't use: border=" bgcolor="<table border=2" bgcolor="#efefef">

column2: > The <table> element is used to add tables to a web page.> A table is drawn out row by row.  Each row is created with the <tr> element.> Inside each row there are a number of cells represented by the <td> element (or <th>) if it is a header.> You can make cells of a table span more than one row or column using the rowspan and colspan attributes.> For long tables you can split the table into a <thead>, <tbody>, and <tfoot>.
> How to collect information from visitors.> Different kinds of form controls.> New HTML5 form controls
Adding Text:text inputpassword inputtext areaMaking Choices:radio buttonscheckboxesdrop-down boxesSubmitting Forms:submit buttonimage buttonsUploading Files:file upload

<form> Structure: action, method (get/post), id1. action attribute: value is URL for page on server that receives info from form when submitted.2. method: get or postA. get method:1. short forms, such as search boxes2. just retrieving data from webserver (not sending info)B. post method:1. values sent in HTTP header. Good for:	a. allows user to upload file.	b. is very long	c. contains sensitive data	d. adds info to, or deletes info from database.3. id<form action=http://www.example.com/subscribe.php" method="get">
